sen.j: 御物
sen.e: Gyobutsu
Gyobutsu
Gyobutsu

sen.j: 御物（ぎょぶつ。「ごもつ」とも）天皇家に伝来した所蔵品のこと。
sen.e: Also called 'Gomotsu', the collections handed down to Imperial families.
Also called 'Gomotsu,' the collections handed down to Imperial families.
Gyobutsu (also called 'Gomotsu') is the collections handed down to Imperial families.

sen.j: （本項で詳述）
sen.e: (There is a description in the main section.)
(There is a description in the main section.)
(There is a description in the main section.)

sen.j: 御物（ごもつ。「ぎょぶつ」とも）室町幕府8代将軍足利義政が集めた唐物名物（絵画、工芸品）を東山御物（ひがしやまごもつ）、徳川家に伝えられた名物茶道具を柳営御物（りゅうえいごもつ、柳営は幕府または将軍の意味）と呼ぶ。
sen.e: Gyobutsu (Gomotsu) Also called 'Gyobutsu', the collection of famous things imported from China (pictures and art works) by AHIKAGA Yoshimasa, the 8th Shogun of Muromachi Shogunate, are called Higashiyama Gobutsu, the others are called Ryuei Gomotsu. (Ryuei is the name of the Shogunate or Shogun)
sen.cmt: 室町幕府 the Muromachi Shogunate 英辞郎 on the WEB, 将軍 Shogun, 足利義政 Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, 茶道具 tea utensil // tea-things 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Gyobutsu (Gomotsu) Also called 'Gyobutsu,' the collection of famous things imported from China (pictures and art works) by AHIKAGA Yoshimasa, the eighth Shogun of Muromachi Shogunate, are called Higashiyama Gobutsu, the others are called Ryuei Gomotsu (Ryuei is the name of the Shogun or the shogunate).

Gomotsu (also called 'Gyobutsu') is the collections of famous things imported from China (pictures and art works) by Yoshimasa AHIKAGA, the eighth shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, are called Higashiyama Gobutsu, and the famous Japanese tea utensils handed down to the Tokugawa clan are called Ryuei Gomotsu (Ryuei is the name of the Shogun or the shogunate).
sen.cmt: 姓名順番入れ替えthe others→the famous Japanese tea utensils handed down to Tokugawa clan訳抜け補足文にまとめました。

sen.j: 御物（おもの）：天皇や貴人の食事のこと。
sen.e: Omono: meals for Emperors and noble people
Omono: meals for Emperors and noble people
Omono: meals for Emperors and noble people

sen.j: 御物（ぎょぶつ）は、日本の皇室の私有品である絵画、書跡、刀剣などを指す用語。
sen.e: Gyobutsu means the collection of pictures or written records and side arms which belonged to Japanese Imperial families.
Gyobutsu refers to the collection of pictures or written records and sidearms that belonged to the Japanese Imperial Family.
Gyobutsu refers to the collection of pictures or written records and sidearms that belonged to the Japanese Imperial Family.

sen.j: 「御物」の用例としては、室町幕府8代将軍足利義政の所蔵品を指して東山御物（ひがしやまごもつ）、徳川家伝来の名物茶道具を指して柳営御物（りゅうえいごもつ）などと言う場合があるが、単に「御物」と言えば皇室の私有物を指し、「ぎょぶつ」と読むのが通例である。
sen.e: The examples of 'Gyobutsu' are Higashiyama Gomotsu which were the collection of ASHIKAGA Yoshimasa, the 8th Shogun of Muromachi Shogunate, and also the one called 'Ryuei Gomotsu which are famous Japanese tea utensil// tea-things handed down to TOKUGAWA clan, however the word 'Gyobutsu' simply means the belongings of Imperial families, it is usually called 'Gyobutsu'.

The examples of 'gyobutsu' are the Higashiyama Gomotsu, which was the collection of ASHIKAGA Yoshimasa, the eighth Shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, and also the one called 'Ryuei Gomotsu, which consists of famous Japanese tea utensils (tea things handed down to the TOKUGAWA clan); however, the word 'Gyobutsu' simply means the belongings of the Imperial Family and is usually referred to as 'gyobutsu.'

The examples of 'gyobutsu' are the Higashiyama Gomotsu, which was the collection of Yoshimasa ASHIKAGA, the eighth shogun of the Muromachi shogunate, and also the one called 'Ryuei Gomotsu, which consists of famous Japanese tea utensils (tea things handed down to the Tokugawa clan); however, the word 'Gyobutsu' simply means the belongings of the Imperial Family and is usually referred to as 'gyobutsu.'

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦以前には、東京・京都・奈良の帝室博物館（現・国立博物館）の所蔵品や奈良・正倉院の宝物なども「御物」であった。
sen.e: Before the World War Ⅱ, the collection of Teishitsu National Museum (current National Museum) in Tokyo Prefecture, Kyoto Prefecture and Nara Prefecture, or treasures of Shoso-in in Nara Prefecture are also called 'Gyobutsu'.
sen.cmt: 帝室博物館 Teishitsu National Museum 定訳不明, 国立博物館 National Museum, 正倉院 Shoso-in 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Before World War II, the collection of the Teishitsu National Museum (currently the National Museum) in Tokyo Prefecture, Kyoto Prefecture and Nara Prefecture, as well as the treasures of Shoso-in in Nara Prefecture, were called 'gyobutsu.'

Before World War II, the collection of the Teishitsu National Museum (currently the National Museum) in Tokyo Prefecture, Kyoto Prefecture and Nara Prefecture, as well as the treasures of Shoso-in in Nara Prefecture, were called 'gyobutsu.'

sen.j: 同大戦後は、日本国憲法第88条の規定に基づき、天皇家の資産は原則として国有財産となり、皇居をはじめ御用地、御用邸、修学院離宮、桂離宮、埼玉鴨場などの土地建物、正倉院の宝物などはすべて国有財産（皇室用財産）となった。
sen.e: In the same period mentioned above, according to Article eighty eight of Japan's constitution, land and buildings like Imperial Palace, Goyochi, Imperial villa, Shugakuin Imperial Villa, Katsura Imperial Villa, Saitama Kamoba (an area designated for duck hunting), and treasures of Shoso-in, all the properties of Imperial families became government property. (property belong to Imperial families)
sen.cmt: 日本国憲法 Article eighty eight of Japan's constitution 英辞郎 on the WEB, 御用地 定訳不明, 御用邸 an Imperial villa 研究社新和英大辞典,,修学院離宮Shugakuin Imperial Villa http://sankan.kunaicho.go.jp/english/index.html, 桂離宮 Katsura Imperial Villa http://sankan.kunaicho.go.jp/english/index.html, 埼玉鴨場 Saitama Kamoba(an area designated for duck hunting) 定訳不明
sen.e: In the same period mentioned above, according to Article 88 of the Japanese Constitution, land and buildings such as the Imperial Palace, Goyochi, Imperial Villa, Shugakuin Imperial Villa, Katsura Imperial Villa, Saitama Kamoba (an area designated for duck hunting), and treasures of Shoso-in, all the properties of the Imperial Family, became government property (property belonging to Imperial families).

After World War II, according to Article 88 of the Japanese Constitution, land and buildings such as the Imperial Palace, Goyochi, Imperial Villa, Shugakuin Imperial Villa, Katsura Imperial Villa, Saitama Kamoba (an area designated for duck hunting), and treasures of Shoso-in, all these being the properties of the Imperial Family, became government property (property belonging to Imperial families).
sen.cmt: In the same period mentioned above→After World War II

sen.j: ただし、日本国憲法下においても、皇室伝来の美術品などは引き続き「御物」と呼ばれ、宮内庁侍従職が管理していた。
sen.e: The art works handed down to Imperial families are still called 'Gyobutsu' under Japan's constitution, they are supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency.
sen.cmt: 宮内庁侍従職 the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency 研究社新和英大辞典
sen.e: The art works handed down to the Imperial Family are still called 'gyobutsu' under the Japanese Constitution, being supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency.
The art works handed down to the Imperial Family are still called 'gyobutsu' under the Japanese Constitution, being supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency.

sen.j: 1988年の昭和天皇の死去に伴い、翌1989年、「御物」の大部分は相続にともなって天皇家から国庫に物納され、宮内庁管轄の三の丸尚蔵館に収蔵されている。
sen.e: After Emperor Showa died in 1988, the most of the 'Gobutsu' were paid in kind from Imperial families to national treasury in the following year of 1989, they were kept in San-no-Maru Museum of The Imperial Collections, which is supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency.
sen.cmt: 昭和天皇 Emperor Showa 研究社新和英大辞典, 三の丸尚蔵館 San-no-Maru Museum of The Imperial Collections 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: After the death of Emperor Showa in 1988, most of the 'gobutsu' was paid in kind from the Imperial Family to the National Treasury in the following year (1989) and was subsequently kept in San-no-Maru Museum of the Imperial Collections, which is supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency.

After the death of Emperor Showa in 1988, most of the 'gyobutsu' was paid in kind from the Imperial Family to the National Treasury in the following year (1989) and was subsequently kept in San-no-Maru Museum of the Imperial Collections, which is supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency.

sen.j: 三の丸尚蔵館所蔵品には狩野永徳筆の「唐獅子図屏風」、絵巻の名品として知られる「春日権現験記絵巻」「蒙古襲来絵詞」、伊藤若冲の代表作「動植綵絵」などが含まれる。
sen.e: The collection at San-no-Maru Museum of The Imperial Collections includes art works like 'Karajishi(Chinese-style figure of a lion)-zu-Byobu(folding Screen)' by Eikotku KANO, 'Kasuga Gongen-ki Emaki(a horizontal picture scroll)', 'Moko-Shurai(the Mongol Invasions)-Ekotoba(an explanation on a picture scroll)', both known as famous picture scroll, Jakuchu ITO's famous art works, 'Dobutsu-saie'.
sen.cmt: 狩野永徳, Eitoku KANO, 「唐獅子図屏風」'Karajishi(Chinese-style figure of a lion)-zu-Byobu(folding Screen)' 研究社新和英大辞典 定訳不明,「春日権現験記絵巻」'Kasuga Gongen-ki Emaki(a horizontal picture scroll) 定訳不明',「蒙古襲来絵詞」'Moko-Shurai(the Mongol Invasions)-Ekotoba(an explanation on a picture scroll)' 研究社新和英大辞典 定訳不明, 伊藤若冲 Jakuchu ITO, 「動植綵絵」'Dobutsu-saie' 定訳不明
sen.e: The collection of the Imperial Collections at the San-no-Maru Museum includes art works like 'Karajishi (Chinese-style figure of a lion)-zu-Byobu (folding screen)' by Eikotku KANO, 'Kasuga Gongen-ki Emaki (a horizontal picture scroll),' 'Moko-Shurai (the Mongol Invasions)-Ekotoba (an explanation on a picture scroll),' both known as famous picture scrolls, and Jakuchu ITO's famous art works, 'Dobutsu-saie.'

The collection of the Imperial Collections at the San-no-Maru Museum includes art works like 'Karajishi (Chinese-style figure of a lion)-zu-Byobu (folding screen)' by Eitoku KANO, 'Kasuga Gongen-ki Emaki (a horizontal picture scroll),' 'Moko-Shurai (the Mongol Invasions)-Ekotoba (an explanation on a picture scroll),' both known as famous picture scrolls, and Jakuchu ITO's famous art works, 'Do-shoku Saie.'

sen.j: これらの作品は、1989年以降は「御物」ではなく国有財産という位置付けになっている。
sen.e: These art works are considered as government property instead of 'Gyobutsu' since 1989.
These art works have, since 1989, been considered to be government property instead of 'gyobutsu.'
These art works have, since 1989, been considered to be government property instead of 'gyobutsu.'

sen.j: ただし、「三種の神器」をはじめとする、皇室にゆかりの深い品々や、歴代天皇・皇族の肖像、遺筆、儀式に用いる刀剣類などの皇室経済法7条にいう、「皇位とともに伝わるべき由緒ある物（『御由緒物』）」については国庫の帰属から除かれ、1989年以降も「御物」と呼ばれている。
sen.e: In the Article seven of Imperial House Economy Act it is said 'the materials with historical background which has close relationship with Imperial families ("Goyuishobutsu")' should not be included as government property, thus historical collections associated with Imperial families such as Three sacred emblems of the imperial family, successive emperor's or Imperial family's portraits, written materials, swords used for Imperial ceremonies, are continued to be called 'Gyobutsu' after 1989.
sen.cmt: 『御由緒物』Goyuishobutsu 読み不明, 三種の神器 three sacred emblems of the imperial family 英辞郎 on the WEB, 皇室経済法 Imperial House Economy Act 英辞郎 on the WEB
sen.e: Article 7 of the Imperial House Economy Act specifies that the materials with historical background being close associated with the Imperial Family (goyuishobutsu) should not be included as government property, thus historical collections associated with the Imperial Family, such as the three sacred emblems of the Imperial Family, the portraits of successive Emperors or the Imperial Family, written materials, and swords used for Imperial ceremonies shall continue to be called 'gyobutsu' after 1989.

Article 7 of the Imperial House Economy Act specifies that the materials with historical background being closely associated with the Imperial Family (goyuishobutsu) should not be included as government property, thus historical collections associated with the Imperial Family, such as the three sacred emblems of the Imperial Family, the portraits of successive emperors or the Imperial Family, written materials and swords used for Imperial ceremonies should continue to be called 'gyobutsu' after 1989.

sen.j: これらの御物は宮内庁侍従職の管理下にあり、おもに皇居内の山里御文庫と京都御所内の東山御文庫に保管されている。
sen.e: These Gyobutsu are supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency and are mainly kept in Yamazato Go-bunko(collection) at Imperial Palace and in Higashiyama Go-bunko(collection) at Kyoto Imperial Palace.
sen.cmt: 山里御文庫 Yamazato Go-bunko(collection) 定訳不明, 京都御所 Kyoto Imperial Palace 英辞郎 on the WEB, 東山御文庫 Higashiyama Go-bunko(collection) 定訳不明
sen.e: These gyobutsu are supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency; they are mainly kept in Yamazato Go-bunko (collection) at the Imperial Palace and in Higashiyama Go-bunko (collection) at Kyoto Imperial Palace.

These gyobutsu are supervised by the Board of Chamberlains of the Imperial Household Agency; they are mainly kept in Yamazato Go-bunko (collection) at the Imperial Palace and in Higashiyama Go-bunko (collection) at Kyoto Imperial Palace.

sen.j: なお、御物は慣例的に文化財保護法による指定の対象外となっており、国宝や重要文化財などには指定されていない。
sen.e: Conventionality the Gyobutsu are not included in Cultural Assets Preservation Act, they are not registered as a national treasure or an important cultural assets// important cultural Properties.
sen.cmt: 文化財保護法 Cultural Assets Preservation Act, 国宝 national treasure, 重要文化財 important cultural assets // important cultural properties
sen.e: Conventionally, the gyobutsu are not included in the Cultural Assets Preservation Act, nor are they registered as national treasures, important cultural assets or important cultural properties.
Conventionally, the gyobutsu are not included in the Cultural Assets Preservation Act, nor are they registered as national treasures, important cultural assets or important cultural properties.

Portraits of Prince Shotoku and two princes were dedicated from Horyu-ji Temple Kenno Gyobutsu (Gyobutsu dedicated temple) in 1878.
